summary: When an inmate leads a rebellion, a young guard tries to survive by impersonating a prisoner.

reviews.content: It's a pretty good movie, but it has some screenplay problems, most of them about credibility.

There are a number of plot points that seem very unlikely, including the one which the whole film revolves around, but that doesn't stop this well-acted and intense Spanish film from being a gripping affair that takes a decent man and pushes him to the brink, as well as taking a good, hard look at how the penal system fails its inmates and desperately needs changing.
Made it through a half hour but couldn't shake this soap-opera kind of feel.
An intense thriller that - i am assuming - really showcases the situation in some prisons and criticism towards government decisions.
Alberto Ammann era impresionante como siempre

"Celda 211" ranks as a particularly compelling prison film. It's not perfect, as the script tends to be a little inconsistent at times in terms of both believability and pacing, but the direction is claustrophobic enough and the acting particularly convincing. Moreover the makers handled the transition of the characters brilliantly and, to top it off, didn't enslave their creation to a forced ending.

Juan, a newly recruited prison warder, is being shown around a prison when he is injured in an accident. While awaiting medical help, he finds himself locked inside with the convicts during a viscous riot. Thinking quickly, he poses as a convict and gains the trust of the leader of the rioting inmates. Juan must try to keep his real identity secret and work covertly with the authorities outside who are desperately trying to regain control of the situation. However, with enemies all around him and concerned for the wellbeing of his wife, the young man finds himself in an increasingly hostile situation. This is a terrific Spanish thriller from director Daniel Monzón. It is a full throttle, macho and violent affair but handled with skill and flair. This isn't the sort of film I'd normally go for but I thoroughly enjoyed watching this gripping movie. Highly recommended.

I never really felt the need to examine the definition of word "Protagonist", that was until I watched Cell 211 (Spanish: Celda 211). Earlier, I had a notion that protagonist should be virtuous and altruistic. I had to refer Oxford English Dictionary which defined protagonist as "the main character in a play, film/movie or book" and that protagonist doesn't necessarily mean the righteous one. Halfway into the film is when you will apprehend the reason why I am boring you with these definitions.    

This 2009 film from Spain is one of the most iconic films about prison politics. The first thing that comes into everyone's mind when they think of prison is "don't drop the soap".  Cell 211 examines the cause and effect of prison subjects very far from much hyped soap business. What if Prison, the very purpose of which is to confine and incarcerate people charged with crimes, uses criminal methods to provide correctional officers with unwarranted advantage over inmates to such extent that one may say enough is enough? If history has taught us anything, it's that nothing is permanent. What if inmates were to stand up against tyranny of correctional officers? Do their past crimes validate the methods used against them? Sometimes the line that separates right from wrong becomes so thin that one may question his judgment and morality. We, as an audience, constantly face this dilemma while trying to pick up sides during the whole length of movie. 

The film has one of the most memorable opening scenes that don't really serve any purpose to the story line but its there for a reason and the reason alone is to warn the audience that this film does not care about their expectations for some kind of release or catharsis. It would be a sin to describe the scene to the uninitiated. It must unfold itself as it slowly grows inside you and sets the tone of the film. The movie starts as an investigation of events leading up to the conclusion of prison riot. Juan Oliver, newly appointed prison officer, decides to take a tour of prison but an accident knocks him unconscious and he is rushed by prison officers to empty but apparently haunted walls of cell 211. In the mean time, murder of another prison guard by an inmate (an extraordinary one) quickly develops into a riot leading to convicts breaking free and hijacking control of the penitentiary. Aware of the violence that is to come, the prison officers flee, leaving Juan stranded and unconscious in the heart of the riot. When Juan awakens, he immediately takes stock of the situation; in order to survive, he must pretend to be a prisoner. 

Cell 211 may be about the chaos of prison riot but its essence lies not in violence but rather in beauty of friendship in the most unusual of circumstances between two polarizing characters, Juan- the prison officer and Malamadre- the inmate. Script transforms into a character study, in which the prison inmate, Malamadre, becomes a scholar of depravity and the younger Juan experiences it in a pitiable and personal way. The enigma of Malamadre's character is at the heart of the film, and this is one of Luis Tosar's best performances. He embodies authority naturally; much like his other works such as Te doy mis ojos 2003. Here he knows all the lessons an inmate might internalize during years spent in what we learn is one of the worst prisons of the country. Malamadre is introduced early into the film and dominates the film from that point forward. This actor is entrusted with big assignment. He embodies Authority. Like Hans Landa, his character must be played by a strong actor who projects not merely villainy but authoritarian. Observe his face- Smug,Self-satisfied. Listen to his voice-Articulate, analytical. Mark his composure and apparent fearlessness. The film essentially depends on him, and would go astray if the actor faltered. He never does.

Elena, Juan's pregnant wife, brings a note of compassion into the picture. Watching the film, we assume Elena's character is simply a place-holder, labeled protagonist's wife and denied much depth. But she is saving her impact until later. The film is fast paced with chaos erupting one after another wherein the flashbacks of intimate moments between Elena and Juan comes into play to provide the story with more passion. The most interesting part is watching Juan win the confidence of Malamadre and other inmates with his wit and playing a double-agent at the same time.

I learn from internet that the name "Malamadre", seemingly so meaningless for us non-Europeans, actually serves a purpose.  Malamadre literally translates into Bad Mother in Spanish which is a plant oftenly called as Spider plant (botanical name Chlorophytum Comosum).  The spider plant is so named because of its spider-like plants, or spiderettes, which dangle down from the mother plant like spiders on a web signifying the persona of Malamadre's inherent character as the inmates' confidante.

Like Malamadre, Cell 211 keeps its words.

If you get through the gory opening scene, then you will probably love the rest of this action-packed prison flick that draws a very fine line between the good guys and the bad guys with its clever conceit: an eager new guard comes in a day before he starts his job and, through a terrible coincidence, gets caught up in a riot for the ages. There's one scene that seems unlikely - slight spoiler, a much-hated guard is thrown to the wolves - but the rest of the movie is white-knuckle drama (with a surprising and interesting political dimension behind it) that takes a character and tests him in a way a few films do. Brave, exciting work that swept the Goyas (Spain's Oscars) in 2009. Definitely see this one.
Awesome prison riot gone wrong movie, gripping to the very end. Bittersweet prison movie.

An outstanding drama to explore how truly thin the line is between both sides of the law.  The character transformation is shocking, especially considering the whole event takes place over one day.  Juan Oliver enters as a soon to be prison guard, and rapidly turns into the very type of person he was supposed to guard.  The things he does to blend in are horrifying, and the actor behind it all is brilliant.  Malamadre also has ample star power and fight between these two leads for prison and screen dominance has great back and forth tension.  Although it allows itself some leniency as far as believability, you get so lost in the story it'll likely go right over your head.  Cell 211 is well acted, astonishing and will likely leave you thankful you're not on the wrong side of prison bars.

Interesting plot, but it feels overlong. Could've been 30 minutes shorter. The plot gets confusing halfway through. Good acting and pretty brutal. Lots of violence and blood. Should please fans of the genre.

A consistently compelling, superbly acted prison drama in which the diverse range of personalities of the rioting inmates don't get lost in the action. The gradual metamorphoses of newbe officer Juan Oliver (a stunning Alberto Ammann) and his relationship with top dog Malamadre (an intense Luis Tosar) is the backbone to the story, with flashbacks and cutaways to Juan's partner Elena (the gorgeous Marta Etura) adding depth to what could've otherwise been just another substandard prison yarn.
Brilliant. A look into the mind of man to see how he changes with his situation. The film had me the whole time.

A friendship soon develops been him and the hard-headed riot leader but as usual life always has a way of changing the game and upping the stakes.

Scores points for the graphic depiction of a prison riot and subsequent siege. The character of Juan Oliver is brilliantly realised by Alberto Ammann as we follow him in his transformation from rookie prison guard to being trapped on the wrong side of the locked doors through a brutal and very rapid onset of Stockholm Syndrome.

The film pulls no punches, even if some of the scenes outside the prison are a bit much and stretch credibility. Some of the prisoners are also caricatures we've seen before, but the performances are committed enough to let that go. It could have scored higher if it had been 10 minutes tighter in the plotting, which would probably have edited out some of the weaker scenes. 

But this is definitely an above-average prison thriller. Apparently there's a Hollywood remake in production. All I'll say is that I hope it sticks with the convictions of its Spanish source material. There are no studio endings here, and some pretty savage plot twists that don't feel at all like normal studio material.
really enjoyed this movie from start to finish. plenty action and great storyline.

The new prison guard finds himself stuck in a riot. He pretends to be an inmate and befriend the leader of the prisoners. Everything goes as you'd expect, nothing new, very conventional stuff. It's effective though, but the movie lost me when the very pregnant wife of the guard goes to a protest-like demonstration in front of the prison cause she wants to know what's really up with her husband. Such stupidity kicked me out of the film and I didn't even care when she obviously got hurt. What the fuck was she doing there in the first place. Otherwise the film is gritty enough, it touches many things and has interesting political implications, but it was too late for me, as I never gotback into it that much. Such a shame.

Cell 211 starts off with a neat premise following the brutal tale of prison guard turned inmate, trying to survive after being mistaken for a new arrival during the course of a blood-thirsty riot. The intense atmosphere is sustained expertly throughout two thirds of the film, showing the growing violence within the prison and the political machinations in the warden's office, leaving the main character Juan Oliver (played by Alberto Ammann) and the audience unsure as to who the true villains are.
Sadly, this tension is not sustained throughout the whole film, and you can actually pinpoint the exact moment when you know it is going to decend into a silly melodrama. I won't tell you when this is, so you can experience saying out loud "this has turned from a five star film into a three star film" simultaneously with your friends as I did when first watching it.
Fans of violent prison dramas will be thrilled reguardless, and it is worth watching just for the exceptional performance of Luis Tosar as the psychotic Malamadre, but this could have been so much better.

Gripping, entertaining, surprisingly violent and with a strong plot, Celda 211 shows us that Spanish cinema isn't only about Almodovar, but also about Tarantino mixed with elements of Nolan.

Dark, gritty, and thought provoking Cell 211 is an A-grade thriller, guided by Luis Tosar and Alberto Ammann's exceptional performances and an intelligent script, the film treads through it's genre full of energy,  astuteness, and originality.

Directed by Daniel Monzon and  starring Luis Tosar and Alberto Ammann, this Spanish Drama involves two men who are involved in a prison riot, one an inmate leading the rebellion, the other a young guard trapped in the violence.

Cell 211 completely contradicted my initial perspective of the film, expecting an action thriller and receiving a powerful drama. The film wastes no time getting into the story as it  begins with the new young employee at the prison, a day early, ready to begin his new job, when all of the sudden the situation spirals out of control until before you know it he's lying in a prison cell bleeding. Although I did feel that this beginning was a little rushed, I do prefer it to when their is a long unnecessary build up to the main story in which your eagerly anticipating.As the film progresses the story becomes ever more interesting and intricate, with the help of the film's superb characters. Malamadre (played by Luis Tosar) delivers a terrifying passionate performance, in my opinion making the film what it is.

However it comes with the characters that brings my biggest disappointment, although the majority of the characters were interesting, I found that most were completely unbelievable and unnecessary. Malmadre's gang is heavily involved in the story but most of them just stand around doing nothing, then occasionally 'pop their head around the door, and drop a bombshell'. Even the character of  Malmadre I thought at times was given an awful piece of dialogue to say which just turned off the intensity of the film and made it a bit unbelievable, obviously this is due down to the screenplay, therefore it would be unfair to judge the actors performances. Some aspects of the characters I believe that they got right, the director ,Daniel Monzon, resists the temptation to create another 'Hollywood hero' and instead creates a much more realistic character who helps to work the film along in a believable manor.

Overall however, despite the frustration over the character's, this film delivers an exciting and punchy drama, worthy of your attention. 

80%

This is an excellent movie from actors' make up & characteristics, set up, dialogue, background setting. Not only the story has been well-researched that truly reflected on the actors and setting and dialog, the flow of the story was awesome, let alone the ending!

The best part is, the movie showed an interesting ending, which leaves more room to the audience to think about its story and message behind.

It's like the wild, unruly, slightly stupid younger brother of Jacques Audiard's superb 2009 film 'A Prophet'.
Brutal and violent and utterly thrilling, Monzon's thuggish Prison Riot drama has more ingenuity and menace than the entire 4-series run of Fox Television's Prison Break. Closer to HBO's Oz, if anything, this features the spectacularly sexy Alberto Ammann in the central role as Prison Officer-playing-criminal, while Luis Tosar hits a career-defining high as 'Malamadre' (or 'Sonofabitch' ) the patriarchal, fiercely loyal, violently unpredictable leader of the prison.

New prison guard Juan (Alberto Ammann) is injured by falling masonry during his introductory tour so his colleagues stick him in vacant cell 211 whilst they call an ambulance. Bad timing, as inmate Malamadre (Luis Tosar) starts a riot and takes some fellow ETA prisoners hostage as leverage - so when Juan is discovered he decides his only course of action is to pretend to be an inmate. This simple but strong idea sets off a gripping chain of events which escalates in alarming fashion, never taking the most obvious direction during its course. What makes Daniel Monzon's film stand head and shoulders above most prison set dramas is its authenticity and the powerhouse performances from its two lead actors.

I was impressed with this Spanish prison drama.  It's suspenseful, tense, and interesting.  A new guard being shown around the prison by other guards winds up abandoned in an empty cell as a full-scale inmate riot breaks out.  Trapped inside the sealed-off block, he successfully passes himself off as a fellow prisoner.  And he's in the special detention block, so his new friends are the worst of the worst.  As the riot progresses and the situation deteriorates, he's forced to do all the things the other inmates do -- up to and including murder.  The unfolding drama outside the cell block, as prison and government officials scramble to rescue not only the trapped guard but a few Basque prisoners the Spanish government doesn't want harmed (lest a new wave of Basque terrorism be unleashed on Spain) is equally tense and suspenseful, and there are plenty of surprises toward the end as informers and turncoats are revealed.  It's a great story.  There are some awfully brutal scenes, and while you may avert your gaze from time to time, you won't be able to tear yourself away from the movie.

Impressive, brutal & surprising, 'Cell 211' ratchets up the tension from its opening, extremely bloody sequence to its final gut-punch scenes. It functions most successfully as a high-concept prison break thriller, as a new guard has to pretend he's a prisoner when a riot breaks out in a maximum security wing. There's more to it though-a character piece about what we might do to survive, on top of a piece of social commentary that recalls Dostoevsky's claim that if you want the measure of a society, look at the way it treats its prisoners. So there's plenty to enjoy an think about here, though on the first viewing at least, you may be too busy biting your nails to consider the hidden depths.

Like "Let the Right One In" and "The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo" this is another European film that has unashamedly been set up for an American remake already (Paul Haggis being the man involved). Seldom are remakes anywhere near as good and yet again, this will prove a hard one to match.
 Juan (Alberto Ammann) is about to start work as a prison guard and is taking a tour of a maximum security area when he is injured slightly in an accident and left behind as a riot breaks out. Juan convinces Malamadre (Luis Tosar), the convicts' leader, that he is a new inmate who has been beaten up by guards, and the two men become close as the crisis escalates.
 The film opens with the look of a low budget television film and at first I began to think I shouldn't have listened to the plaudits I'd read of this. Not before long though, it really kicks into gear and cranks up the tension and excitement. Within minutes I was hooked. I'm an avid fan of prison drama's, with their high level of suspense and on edge atmosphere and sense of danger. This is no different and wastes no time in exposing you to the violence and brutality of the inmates. Helped no end by two excellent central performances, particulary Luis Tosar as the snarling dominant ring leader. Director Daniel Monzon keeps the story briskly moving with several moments of unbearable and skillfully handled suspense and the fact that it avoids the usual genre conventions with many unexpected plot developments, helps in keeping you captivated and wondering what direction it will go in. European cinema seems to be reaching a bigger audience these days and this is another worthy of attention. 
 Fans of the 2009 French film "A Prophet", or any prison drama for that matter, should find plenty to enjoy here. An excellent well crafted film that delivers tension in spades.

What ensues is a tense, dramatic film that is brutally harsh and very well acted. Malamadre is the head honcho and he and his cronies have taken over the prison in retaliation to being treated like the scum that they are by the system and Juan just wants to be with his heavily pregnant wife and will do what it takes to try and stay alive.

El "Malamadre" es otra de esas grandes creaciones de Luis Tosar, especialista en interpretar villanos, al "malo" de la historia. Tosar es la fuerza motriz de Celda 211 (2009), y es quien lleva la batuta como el líder de un motín en una prisión estatal madrileña. Rapado, con barba tupida, mirada que mata enmarcada con sus pobladas cejas y una voz de Popeye, Luis Tosar crea un personaje que, literalmente, pone a temblar. No por nada fue el ganador del Goya a "Mejor Actor" en 2010, mientras que Daniel Monzón, el realizador, el de "Mejor Director".

Como el título indica, Celda 211 es un drama carcelario eficiente, llevado con un timing impresionante por Monzón. Prácticamente, toda la historia se desarrolla dentro de la cárcel. El nuevo guardia del lugar, Juan Oliver (el argentino Alberto Amman, magnífico), ha decidido empezar un día antes con un recorrido por el lugar, en donde le es dada importante información por otros dos guardias, como detalles sobre el comportamiento, movimientos y jerarquías de los presos. "Te acostumbrarás. Al final, ellos se irán yendo, pero tú te quedarás aquí toda la vida", le dice "alentadoramente" uno de los guardias a Juan.
La puesta en escena nos hace respirar el ambiente en la prisión. Filmada con cámara digital, no hay rincón en esa cárcel en donde no nos sintamos incómodos, claustrofóbicos y, en muchas partes, presos de la ansiedad, cada vez que el "Malamadre" toma una decisión, reflexiona, o ve su liderazgo amenazado. Aunque tampoco pude dejar de sentirme angustiado por ver en qué momento el plan de Juan se viene abajo. Es decir, Celda 211 es una película que funciona en todos los niveles. En pocas palabras, o como seguramente diría el "Malamadre", es un filme "acojonante".

Impressive, gritty Spanish prison drama

I really enjoyed this prison drama from Spain. It is gritty, raw and debatably realistic, but most importantly entertaining. It's characters are likeable and diverse and the leads are captivating, for what is a macho, adrenaline fuelled play.

The film is about a new prison guard who gets locked in with the inmates after a riot breaks out. He pretends to be a prisoner himself, to stay alive, and fight for a way out to be reunited with his pregnant wife. The film heads down a gritty, dark outcome route (somewhat predictable) as he teams up with the jail leading psycho (Malamadre) to fight the system.

I would argue this is more accessible than other foreign arty films such as Prophet and Elite Squad, and being much better than recent prison based films (Experiment, Dog Pound and co) being essentially gratifying, without being too supercilious, arty or serious.

Males (15-40) should especially love this film (if you can stand the subtitles and light culture) and I recommend it to film fans, suggesting it is more entertaining than anything of wow note or of recognition.

A bracing and exciting thriller that carries strong social commentary without sacrificing on delivering an adrenaline rush. Cell 211 is fast, frightening, and a powerful statement on prison conditions and police brutality.

What would you do if you were a prison guard caught in the middle of a riot, and every other inmate believes you're one of them, while you have an injured wife in the hospital? Juan Oliver (Alberto Amman), a young man who just started working in a prison as a guard, wants to make a good impression and goes a day before his scheduales first day. At the same time, the inmates inside, lead by dangerous Malamadre (Luis Tosar), start a riot. While all of the guards escape of the prison, Juan is knocked unconscious in an accident. He then wakes up in Cell 211. He wakes up and passes himself as an inmate and befriends Malamdre. While all of this is happening, Elena, Juan's pregnant wife, learns about the riot and goes to the prison to make sure Juan is okay. But during the disturbings outside she is fatally injured. Juan starts working undercover for the police so he can inform them about the riot, and help them with the negociations.

The film is like The Shawshank Redemption crossed with The Departed. This Spanish thriller is little known, but what a great film it is. The whole film I was intrigued, thrilled and on the edge of my seat. Daniel Monzon, a new Spanish director, makes this thrilling and creates the whole world of the prison. He works very careful on every detail of the film, and the result was fantastic. A very good director, and I hope he makes more films this good in the future.

The story and characters were great and touching. The screenwriters do a terrific job. The premise is thrilling, and put into screen is better. A very dangerous situation, that not many men would put themselves through. They do a very good job also with the characters. From the harmless and delicate Elena, to the dangerous Malamadre, all the characters are the way they're supposed to be: human. They show their flaws and their attributes. The characters that are supposed to be likeable they are, and other character that we should hate we hate them. Even Malamadre, who seems to be one of those characters we are supposed to hate, as the story progresses we start liking him. And we can't help it but feel sorry for the poor Juan Oliver, who not only is on a life and death situation but also his wife is on the hospital and has committed crimes since he got into the prison that might get him in ail, plus if the other inmates discover about his true identity he's dead!

The performances were top notch. Alberto Amman, who plays Juan, does a fantastic job with his character and all his scenes. While he slowly descends, we can truly see the transformation Juan is suffering through him. Marta Etura, who plays Elena, also does a very good job here. The indefense Elena is put into the screen through this fantastic actress in a very good way. But the highlights for the acting goes to Luis Tosar, who plays riot leader Malamadre. He truly steals the show. I think this might be one of the greatest performances in a foreign film, and possibly in cinema. From simple expressions to powerful scenes of anger, he masters it all. He is definetly the best actor in this film. He doesnt play Malamadre, he becomes Malamadre.

This film is fantastic. From the story and characters to the amazing performances to the impressive direction, this film is great in everything it does. The film won 8 Goya Awards including Best Picture, Director, Screenplay and Actor for Luis Tosar, all well deserved. And the film definitely deserved an Academy Award nomination for Best Foreign Language Film, and possibly to have won. For those who enjoy prison films and thriller films, and don't mind reading subtitles they should check this one out. But good luck finding it! And trust me, it is worth the time and money you might spend looking for it.

You simply cannot know how you will react to traumatic circumstances until you are thrust into the middle of the storm. If you are Juan Oliver in the film Cell 211 you quickly discover that surviving at all costs is both a skill and an instinctive response. I'm not sure how realistic this film is in the quest to portray dilapidated prison conditions which house Spain's worst offenders, but I sure hope I never have to find out. Besides, the film does not come across as a political message about the lives of prisoners in Spain, it is more or less a simple story of survival for one man trapped in a nightmare who has to make unthinkable choices at every turn. Perhaps there is more significance to those in Spain or the surrounding area, but as an American viewer I appreciated the film as an entertaining and intriguing story all by itself.

One day before he is to start his new job as a prison guard at a Zamora prison, Juan Oliver kisses his pregnant young wife and goes to take a tour of the facilities. He is given the tour by 2 of his soon to be co-workers and he learns briefly about the conditions of the DSS prisoners - those who are marked for special surveillance and spend almost all of their time in solitary confinement taking regular beatings from officers. A split second later everything changes for Oliver. A freak accident leaves him injured just as a riot breaks out in the prison. Left with a choice to help him or save themselves the two guards bolt leaving Oliver stranded and wounded in the empty cell 211. When he awakens he is foggy but must quickly determine how to survive. Passing himself off cleverly as a new inmate, Oliver must gain the trust of everyone or be killed on the spot.

Though staying on the good side of everyone in the riot is important, it is really only the opinion of the riot leader, Malamadre, that matters. A brutal killer with nothing to lose, he is well versed in the prison system and the art of negotiation. He knows that a riot is the only way to get better conditions in any form from the prison or the government, but usually once the riot is over the demands which were met are quickly dismissed. This time he has a better plan that includes the hostage taking of 3 political prisoners of great importance. 

The film contains some cliche moments and some caricatured characters, but overall the interplay between Oliver and Malamadre is superb. One is a regular guy, decent, the other a complex murderer, and it is up to Oliver to make sure their relationship stays civil. Along the way Oliver must make personal sacrifices which border on the unthinkable, and in the end he must struggle greatly with a turn that he could have never foreseen.

The film is shot in a grainy texture that I admire for the subject matter, and though you have to suspend disbelief for some of the plot, the overall theme is carried well throughout and sometimes portrayed with brutal and striking violence. Psychologically this is a strong film that will leave you thinking as the credits roll. The film won 8 Goya awards, which is equivalent to a film sweeping the Oscars. I'm not sure it deserves all that, but it is definitely a worthy film of your time.

Cell 211 (2009)

Brutal!
However you must see this film.
Now, Im no fan of gratuitous violence. Splatter films without sufficient irony bore me. Soulless brutality pisses me off. 
However, if you love movies, you must see this film.

Cell 211 smashes onto the screen with a cover-your-eyes graphic wrist slitting suicide. Youve got my attention, but what else have you got? Everything.

The story is set in a present-day Spanish prison during a riot and is as taut a thriller as Ive ever seen. The set up is a new prison guard Juan Oliver (relative newcomer to the screen, Alberto Ammann) is getting an orientation the day before he starts. Falling masonry from a maintenance operation renders him unconscious. His fellow guards decide to put him in cell 211 and bring the doctor to him. Oops, the charismatic leader of the prisoners Malamadre (Luis Tosar, Ive seen him in Limits of Control) chooses that moment to launch a riot to force the administration to address the prisoners grievances. 

Tension? How will Juan survive? He pretends to be a prisoner.  Dont see it on a full bladder. 

Cringe moments worthy of Reservoir Dogs? Yes, but theyre rooted in the essence of a great story, not slapped on for effect. Every fountain of blood means something important. Awesome adapted screenplay by Director Daniel Monzon and co-writer Jorge Guerricaechevarria that ups the stakes at every story beat.

Social redeeming importance? Yes, it has the elements of an exposé but manages to keep that subtly in the background. It also manages to increase the tension by throwing in a political dimension with a handful of ETA political prisoners. 

Inspired cinematography and sound? The sounds and pictures magnify the dynamic of the drama and even manage to create heart-stopping images of beauty without detracting from the gritty reality. Kudos to cinematographer (Take My Eyes) who has worked with Monzon several times before and to Roque Banos (Sexy Beast, The Machinist) for an empathetic score that knows its place. .

Great characters? Oodles of them. Malamadre is both brutal and cunning, but has a thirst for justice. Juan; he descends the elevator to hell as he tries to play both sides of the game.  The sly, duplicitous rival of Malamadre, Apache (Carlos Barden, yes, hes Javiers brother) and the ineffectual bureaucratic head of the prison ( Manolo Solo, Pans Labyrinth).  Throw in prison guards trying to do the right thing, Juans pregnant wife, brutal prison guards, the SWAT team standing by to end the riot by any means necessary, prisoners running amok, lying, scum-bag politicians and Cell 211 delivers fist in-the-face drama with a side order of teeth-clenching tension.

Monzon uses his relatively small (by Hollywood standards) 5.7 million dollar budget to outclass any number of soulless action films and he cleaned up at the Goyas (Spanish film awards). Its criminal that this film hasnt received a wider US release. 

If you love tension married to great drama (and can get past a few cringe moments), You must see this film.
Not for the weak of heart. Great movie though. The story takes you inside the brutality of a prison riot and gives you a psychology trip of right and wrong.

Wow! Surprisingly a very entertaining prison revolt action packed drama that has the capacity to keep you at the edge of your seat. The story of this 8 Goya Award winning (Spanish Oscars!) film follows a newly hired prison officer finds himself in the midst of a prison riot after an unforeseen turn of events. With the inmates around him unaware of his position, he must pretend to be a prisoner to survive. As from the beginning with mounting amount of tension the story evolves in unexpected ways, changing our perceptions of characters and the situation again and again. This film has it all, intelligence, action, drama, suspense, sadness and even a dash of comedy through all the madness. Kudos to the director & the entire cast for their spectacular performance that mostly contributed to made it so intense & engaging till the end.

CELL 211 was Spain's big Goya winner [their Oscars] earning 16 nominations and six wins from Best Film to Actor, Director and Screenplay.  Why am I not surprised when I clearly should be.  Prison movies, especially those clashing the police with its inmates has long existed in the most exploitative of state.  Later on, world filmmakers saw the opportunity to politicize the genre and make bold statements. In 1984 even Israel produced BEYOND THE WALLS about Arab-Israeli clashes within the prison system.  It went on to foreign acclaim.  Well 25 years later, Spain has it's own rebellion headliner of sorts.  The long-stemming rivalry between the Spaniards and the Basques is used here to channel a formulaic nail biter in which a new prison guard is accidentally left behind bars during an uprising and tries his survival instincts by playing for favours with the leader of the revolt. While never boring, it has the pacing of a serialized drama and lacks in depth of characters.  Everybody speaks with a tele-roman sense of urgency and the socio-political elements are washed out in favour of overly saturated histrionics.

Its funny how one flaw in a movie can make all the difference between an enjoyable time or an exasperating experience.  "Cell 211," a Spanish prison thriller, is absorbing for about 30 minutes  but then a key relationship that does not ring true spoils all the fun.

The movie has a clever premise:  A rookie prison guard has just walked into the joint when all hell breaks loose.  There is a riot, violence and, in the confusion, young trainee Juan (Alberto Ammann) is mistaken for one of the inmates. He becomes trapped with hundreds of vicious cons as tense negotiations begin between prison officials and the inmates leader, Malamadre (Luis Tosar).

And this is where the movie lost me.  Implausibly, the tough, shrewd Malamadre is so impressed by a couple of seemingly pro-inmate suggestions made by newcomer Juan that the hardened con and the stubble-faced young man quickly become Best Friends Forever.  This plot absurdity turns what might have been a tense thrill ride into a series of yeah, right moments.

I dont generally read a lot of reviews before writing mine, but yesterday I noticed two local scribes with opposite takes on "Cell 211."  Said Critic Number One: It's a great, simple premise, and I will be surprised if we don't get an American remake  this may be one case where a remake is justified.  Said Critic Number Two: I'll bet you $100 that Hollywood snaps up this property for a glossy, star-studded remake.  I'll bet you $1,000 that this version is better.

Im taking the side of Critic Number One.  For once, Hollywood has the opportunity to actually improve on a foreign film.

¡España campeón! Y gran hacedor de películas, mucho antes de que imagináramos a España campeón del mundo en futbol conocíamos su gran capacidad para contar historias por medio de películas. En esta ocasión nos presentan un filme donde un nuevo policía aún vestido de civil es conducido por la prisión en la que va a laborar cuando se golpea e inicia un motín lo que ve obligados a sus compañeros policías abandonarlo en medio de una situación sumamente peligrosa. Una vez que se recupera se da cuenta de lo grave de la situación por lo que se ve obligado a hacerse pasar por un preso más para intentar salir vivo.

Filme bien realizado con poco presupuesto. Es difícil acostumbrarse al acento y lo ronco del líder de los prisioneros, pero después de 10 min de escucharlo lo entenderán perfectamente. Algunos personajes me parecieron por momentos sobreactuados, otros innecesarios. Pero la relación que se va formando entre los personajes principales me pareció muy bien llevada. Es un filme que vale la pena y bien si apoyamos el cine Mexicano por que no apoyar un buen cine Español.

This is a cracking prison-break suspense drama with a difference - its a newly employed warden who must escape a prison in riot before his inmates find out he's not one of them. Relentlessly tense, cleverly plotted and terrifically played, this is a clammy, edge of your seat experience. Film also has a few things to say about the treatment of prisoners, but it is first and foremost a piece of entertainment, and a very well crafted one at that.
